channel.title: Java.net JIRA
channel.description: An XML representation of a search request

item.title: [JSR_310-26] getFirstMonthOfQuarter Javadoc typo
item.description:
In Javadoc for QuarterOfYear.getFirstMonthOfQuarter

https://jsr-310.dev.java.net/nonav/doc-2010-06-22/javax/time/calendar/QuarterOfYear.html#getFirstMonthOfQuarter%28%29

"To obtain the other two months ..." should read other "three" months.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: There are three months in a quarter - the first, and the "other two".

item.title: [JSR_310-25] LocalTime methods
item.description:
LocalTime.java class in jsr-310-ri-core-20100209 contains two methods :

1) toSecondsOfDay() that returns an int as the time as seconds of day, from 0 to
24 * 60 * 60 - 1.
2) fromSecondsOfDay(long secondOfDay) takes as parameter a long instance which
is the second of day, from 0 to 24 * 60 * 60 â€“ 1

Ideally either toSecondsOfDay should return a Long or fromSecondsOfDay should
take an int.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Replaced by https://github.com/ThreeTen/threeten/issues/254

item.title: [JSR_310-24] Zone Rule
item.description:
Hi,

I'm just playing with the API. It seems the zone rule for Asia/Calcutta is not
defined.

I'm getting an exception when I run a sample code.

Exception in thread "main" javax.time.CalendricalException: Unknown time zone
region: TZDB:Asia/Calcutta
at javax.time.calendar.zone.ZoneRulesGroup.getVersions
(ZoneRulesGroup.java:281)
at javax.time.calendar.zone.ZoneRulesGroup.getRules
(ZoneRulesGroup.java:328)
at javax.time.calendar.TimeZone.of(TimeZone.java:219)
at javax.time.calendar.Clock.systemDefaultZone(Clock.java:112)

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
This time-zone was renamed to Asia/Kolkata. The EDR1 code doesn't handle the
alias to the old name.

This has been fixed now in svn.

item.title: [JSR_310-23] TestDuration fails on latest JDK7
item.description:
Not sure how 'concrete' the current changes in JDK7 are, but using JDK7 b72,
there are failures in 2 tests in javax.time.TestDuration: factory_parseFailures
and factoryParseFailures_comma both fail on each of the 2 data points "PT+0S"
and "PT+1S".

From a quick inspection, this seems to be because the contract of Long.parseLong
has changed from

"The characters in the string must all be decimal digits, except that the first
character may be an ASCII minus sign '-' (\u002D') to indicate a negative value."

in JDK6 to

" ... to indicate a negative value or an ASCII plus sign '+' ('\u002B') to
indicate a positive value."

hence the expected NumberFormatException is not being thrown.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: This was obviously fixed a long time ago!

item.title: [JSR_310-22] JarZoneRulesDataProvider does not cope with Classloader of BEA weblogic
item.description:
it's probably a bug within the classloader of BEA weblogic (10.3):

within JarZoneRulesDataProvider

Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader().getResources("javax/time/calendar/zone/ZoneRuleInfo.dat")

returns duplicate URLs (what causes errors during registation of duplicate
zones). Attached is a simple patch to make URLs unique. It "works for me" (tm)
but why load multiple zones at all?
item.summary: JarZoneRulesDataProvider does not cope with Classloader of BEA weblogic

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Created an attachment (id=13)
patch for problem above
Loaded jar files are deduplicated as per recommendation.

item.title: [JSR_310-21] Date formating and Arabic digits
item.description:
Hi,
When formatting numbers for the Arabic locales, the European digits are used
instead of the Arabic digits. While some Arabic locales might use European
digits as a default this is not the case everyone [1].

Locale.setDefault(new Locale("ar", "EG"));
DateTimeFormatter f = new DateTimeFormatterBuilder().
appendValue(ISOChronology.yearRule(), 4, 10, SignStyle.EXCEEDS_PAD).
appendLiteral('-').
appendValue(ISOChronology.monthOfYearRule(), 2).
appendLiteral('-').
appendValue(ISOChronology.dayOfMonthRule(), 2).
optionalStart().
appendOffset("Z", true, false).
optionalStart().
appendLiteral('[').appendZoneId().appendLiteral(']').toFormatter();

//This will print the date in European digits
System.out.println(f.print(LocalDate.date(2008, 6, 3)));

Current SE date formatting API contains same bug [1] unfixed, Here is a workaround:

Locale.setDefault(new Locale("ar", "EG"));
SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat("d MMMM yyyy");
DecimalFormat df = (DecimalFormat) sdf.getNumberFormat();
DecimalFormatSymbols dfs = df.getDecimalFormatSymbols();
// set the beginning of the range to Arabic digits
dfs.setZeroDigit('\u0660');
df.setDecimalFormatSymbols(dfs);

After digging in current jsr-310 API, I believe
DateTimeFormatSymbols::getZeroChar() should return \u0660

Thanks,
Mina R Waheeb

[1] http://bugs.sun.com/view_bug.do?bug_id=4336841

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

comments.comment:
Clearly there needs to be a way to output Arabic numerals. The question is
whether that should be the default? For a format like ISO8601, the values would
need to be ASCII for example. So, how often do we use locale based vs data based?

Yes, its should be default and in the same time ISO8601 from data point of view
must not use none ASCII.

Lets makes a difference between using ISO8601 from machine to machine and output
the ISO8601 to the end user (log,screen etc..)

1 - If server transmitting ISO8601 date over network and with a specific
protocol, it must make sure from the data formatted right (for example: by
setting the locale to EN and ignoring the default system locale or using
NoneLocaleAwareFormatter).

2 - If swing program output ISO8601 to the screen. It shouldn't follow the
standard format, its just a format for output.

Part of the idea behind the locale is to switch program output to understandable
output for the users using this locale, from machine to machine there is just
formatting and timezone.

Maybe MachineDateTimeFormatter ignores the locale would be a solution for this
problem. We should have LocaleAwareFormatter and NoneLocaleAwareFormatter, The
backward compatibility should play a role in this.

Thanks,
Mina R Waheeb

item.title: [JSR_310-18] Update Ant build file
item.description:
The current build script is good, but could do with a little work:

  • there needs to be a jar produced with the Open JDK code in it
    (currently not compiled at all) This jar will have a different license
    and (currently) requires JSK 6 to compile against. The associated tests
    should also be run for these classes.
  • there needs to be a script added to compile the time zone files into a
    matching .dat file. There should then be a time zone data jar file
    produced containing multiple .dat files. (this will probably require a
    change to the svn layout to allow multiple versions of the tz source
    data to be checked in, and compiled.
  • There should be a combined jar produced containing the contents of the
    three other jars (main, open-jdk derived, tz dat)

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: I already started working on this issue.

Ok, I am back and will have some free time in the next weeks to work on this issue.

But I am not sure should we do it. Should we refactor the existing build file or
should we start an second, alternative build file which will replace the
existing one later?

The existing file is a good start.

svn is now laid out differently, and includes a dedicated structure for multiple
versions of the time zone files. The ant script should have a property file to
specify which of the time zone files are included and which are excluded from
compilation. See TZDBZoneRulesCompiler

Created an attachment (id=12)
Enhanced build.xml to compile and jar all 3 parts independently. Patch against rev 842

Hello, I just submitted a patch for the build.xml. It enhances build.xml to
compile and jar all three source parts separately of each other.

If someone approves this patch, I would like to go on with building an own jar
for the timezone data.
Lots of changes and enhancements to build script now made, including these. Thanks.

item.title: [JSR_310-17] MonthDay and YearMonth parsers
item.description:
Implement static parsers, tests, and javadocs for MonthDay and YearMonth using
format subpackage similar to LocalDate.parse()

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: implementing MonthDay parse and tests

I updated the code you'd checked in. I think this one is done for now (I'd like
to be able to parse 200806 as June 2008, but the formatters don't allow that
right now.
Yes, the changes you made are much cleaner.

item.title: [JSR_310-16] Adds a parse method to LocalTime
item.description:
This is a patch to add a parse method to local time. Note that there were some scenarios
that didn't seem like they should pass strict parsing, but did because the seconds had to be
optional. Not sure if that is a bug in the Formatter, or if the Formatter should be built
differently.
item.summary: Adds a parse method to LocalTime

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Created an attachment (id=6)
A patch created in IDEA 8.1 containing the changes

Created an attachment (id=7)
A better patch with javadoc

Use the second patch, as it adds javadoc comments. I'd like to work on DateTime parser,
but I need some feedback on this patch first. I couldn't get the parser to both parse 00:00
as a time and 00:00:00 without using the Optional addition, but that accepts anything in the
second field - it isn't strict, so that part is still kind of broken.

Not quite sure I know what you mean. Times such as 00:00:05 are perfectly valid.

Your patch does use addValue(hourRule()) whereas it should have
addValue(hourRule(), 2) to ensure two digits are parsed. You can tighten further
using addValue(hourRule(), 2, 2, SignStyle.NEVER) to prevent negatives.

It is OK for the parse() to parse 26:76:85. This is because the mergStrict()
phase will reject it.

Well, the issue is not how it parses hours, but rather that it allows cases like:

00:00:00-09

or 00:00:00.fsb

Those kinds of cases are in the DataProvider for the bad scenarios in the test,
but they are commented out because the test would fail. If I didn't wrap the
seconds in an optional, it wouldn't accept such formatting, but it also would
not accept 00:00 as a legitimate time, as it was then missing the second
component in the provided string.

So I guess the solution lies in either adding an option to appendOptional to
tell it to be strict or using more than one parser (or I'm just ignorant about
something in the API that handles this). I played with it last night, it would
need three. One for 00:00, one for 00:00:00 and one for 00:00:00.00. The messy
part was knowing which one to use. Using some regular expression checking seems
rather ugly, as does trying and catching exceptions.

OK, I understand the problem now. Its really a bug, as the parse() method on a
formatter is supposed to fail if it doesn't use up the whole of the input string.

Created an attachment (id=8)
A patch that includes a fix for the parser.

I attached a patch which addresses the parser bug as well. All of the tests pass after putting
it in, and the LocalTime tests will fail without the patch to the parser, but there are no direct
tests on the parser to document the behavior.
Patch applied, with some tweaks, thanks

item.title: [JSR_310-13] Missing Methods in OffsetDate...
item.description:
There are some methods in LocalDate are missing in OffsetDate. This isn't a huge
problem, because OffsetDate returns a reference to it's private LocalDate
object. But, it would be nice to have isLeapYear(), toEpochDays(),
toModifiedJulianDays() and other methods in both classes.

Maybe there should be a single common interface for these two date classes to
provide a predictable way of determining common methods?

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
I've removed isLeapYear() for now. date.toYear().isLeap() works just as well.

I'm not planning on adding toEpochDays() and toModifiedJulianDays() elsewhere.
On OffsetDate they become more confusing, as an offset of +18 hours will be a
different day to an offset of -18 hours.

item.title: [JSR_310-12] TestDayOfWeek and TestMonthOfYear fail...
item.description: Tests for TestDayOfWeek and TestMonthOfYear fail.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
Fix for TestMonthOfTheYear:
Index: src/test/java/javax/time/calendar/field/TestMonthOfYear.java
===================================================================
— src/test/java/javax/time/calendar/field/TestMonthOfYear.java
(revision 720)
+++ src/test/java/javax/time/calendar/field/TestMonthOfYear.java (working
copy)
@@ -244,7 +244,7 @@
Locale ptBR = new Locale("pt", "BR");
assertEquals(MonthOfYear.JANUARY.getText(ptBR), "Janeiro");
assertEquals(MonthOfYear.FEBRUARY.getText(ptBR), "Fevereiro");

  • assertEquals(MonthOfYear.MARCH.getText(ptBR), "Mar?o");
    + assertEquals(MonthOfYear.MARCH.getText(ptBR), "MarÃ§o");
    assertEquals(MonthOfYear.APRIL.getText(ptBR), "Abril");
    assertEquals(MonthOfYear.MAY.getText(ptBR), "Maio");
    assertEquals(MonthOfYear.JUNE.getText(ptBR), "Junho");

Fix for TestDayOfWeek:
Index: src/test/java/javax/time/calendar/field/TestDayOfWeek.java
===================================================================
— src/test/java/javax/time/calendar/field/TestDayOfWeek.java (revision 720)
+++ src/test/java/javax/time/calendar/field/TestDayOfWeek.java (working copy)
@@ -166,7 +166,7 @@
assertEquals(DayOfWeek.WEDNESDAY.getShortText(ptBR), "Qua");
assertEquals(DayOfWeek.THURSDAY.getShortText(ptBR), "Qui");
assertEquals(DayOfWeek.FRIDAY.getShortText(ptBR), "Sex");

  • assertEquals(DayOfWeek.SATURDAY.getShortText(ptBR), "S?b");
    + assertEquals(DayOfWeek.SATURDAY.getShortText(ptBR), "SÃ¡b");
    assertEquals(DayOfWeek.SUNDAY.getShortText(ptBR), "Dom");
    }

@@ -196,11 +196,11 @@
public void test_getText_pt_BR()

{ Locale ptBR = new Locale("pt", "BR"); assertEquals(DayOfWeek.MONDAY.getText(ptBR), "Segunda-feira"); - assertEquals(DayOfWeek.TUESDAY.getText(ptBR), "Ter?a-feira"); + assertEquals(DayOfWeek.TUESDAY.getText(ptBR), "TerÃ§a-feira"); assertEquals(DayOfWeek.WEDNESDAY.getText(ptBR), "Quarta-feira"); assertEquals(DayOfWeek.THURSDAY.getText(ptBR), "Quinta-feira"); assertEquals(DayOfWeek.FRIDAY.getText(ptBR), "Sexta-feira"); - assertEquals(DayOfWeek.SATURDAY.getText(ptBR), "S?bado"); + assertEquals(DayOfWeek.SATURDAY.getText(ptBR), "SÃ¡bado"); assertEquals(DayOfWeek.SUNDAY.getText(ptBR), "Domingo"); }
Code changed to use \u0000 notation.

item.title: [JSR_310-11] ZoneRuleInfo-Olson-2008i.dat not found in Clock.system()
item.description:
I get an IllegalArgumentException: Unable to load zone rules, file not found...
when trying to run the examples or invoke Clock.system(). I fixed by added the
ZonRuleInfo-Olson-2008i.dat file to the build folder, but my guess is that the
build.xml needs to be modified.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
I have a similar problem when I try to compile the examples. The
OlsonTimeZoneDataProvider cannot locate the timezone database.

I just checked the svn repository. ZoneRuleInfo-Olson-2008i.dat is present at
the right directory.

The problem is, that the timezone database isn't copied to the build directory
before/after compilation. So it is not available at the class path, hence it
could not be loaded/found at runtime.

here is a temporary un-official work around....

<target name="compile" depends="init" description="compile the source">
<mkdir dir="$

{build.main}" />
<javac srcdir="${src.main}" destdir="${build.main}

" classpathref="main.path" />
<copy file="$

{src.main}

/javax/time/calendar/zone/ZoneRuleInfo-Olson-2008i.dat"
todir="$

{build.main}

/javax/time/calendar/zone/" />
</target>

This particular issue is now fixed in svn. However, the ant scripts still need a
lot of work (for example, the time zone source data ends up in the final jar)

item.title: [JSR_310-8] Initializing a Clock with default TimeZone UTC failed
item.description:
If you set the default TimeZone on a system (tested with Windows XP and
Ubuntu-Linux) to UTC, The TimeZone-ID from
java.util.TimeZone.getDefault().getID() returns "UTC" on Windows and "Universal"
on Linux. Parsing of both string faild in TimeZone.timeZone.

How to reproduce:
1) Set the default time zone on your system to UTC
2) Start Java-App and let this code run: Clock clock = Clock.system();
item.summary: Initializing a Clock with default TimeZone UTC failed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
The string 'UTC' should parse now. Universal doesn't work until we pick up the
zone aliases.
Time zone "Universal" now works in svn.

item.title: [JSR_310-6] Define a strategy for implementing equals(Object) and hashCode()
item.description:
Currently, several strategies are being used in different places in the codebase
for implementing equals(Object) and hashCode(). A single documented strategy
should be picked up and used consistently instead.
item.summary: Define a strategy for implementing equals(Object) and hashCode()

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Have we still got any different strategies?
Don't seem to be any different strategies now

item.title: [JSR_310-5] Handle leap seconds
item.description:
Leap seconds should be handled somehow by the API. Should it be supported only
by Instants and Durations? Which other classes? How is it going to be handled?

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Leap seconds were removed from the API. A "Java time scale" was added instead.

item.title: [JSR_310-4] Era.RULE.isSupported() is broken
item.description:
TestLocalDate.test_isSupported() is failing because Era.RULE.isSupported() is
broken. Here is the stack trace for r319:

java.lang.NullPointerException
at javax.time.calendar.DateTimeFieldRule.isSupported(DateTimeFieldRule.java:136)
at javax.time.calendar.LocalDate.isSupported(LocalDate.java:192)
at javax.time.calendar.TestLocalDate.test_isSupported(TestLocalDate.java:241)

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Era class has been deleted

item.title: [JSR_310-3] Make java.xtime.Duration more user-friendly
item.description:
When browsing the jsr-310 API doc, I stumbled upon the Duration class which
struck me as rather sub-optimal:
Why ist there no unit assigned to a Duration?
Why is it restricted to holding a 'seconds' value and a fractional part
expressed in 'nanoseconds'?
Why can't you add/subtract Durations with arbitrary precisions to/from each other?

Or, to sum it up: why isn't it as elegantly designed as this Duration class:

http://www.neppert.com/duration/doc/index.html

OK, I'm prejudiced because I wrote that one

But it really has some distinctive features:

  • integrates seamlessly with java.util.concurrent.*
  • represents a Duration as a number plus a unit plus an optional fractional part
    that is Duration itself.
  • allows lossless transformations between Durations with different units.

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.

item.title: [JSR_310-2] Write tests that serialize instances when appropriate
item.description:
For every class that is supposed to be serializable, tests that actually
serialize and deserialize singleton and regular instances should be written.

comments.comment: This has done along the way to OpenJDK integration

item.title: [JSR_310-1] ZoneOffset serialization is broken
item.description:
The following exception is thrown when a ZoneOffset instance is deserialized:

java.lang.NullPointerException
at javax.time.calendar.ZoneOffset.zoneOffset(ZoneOffset.java:143)
at javax.time.calendar.ZoneOffset.readResolve(ZoneOffset.java:338)
at java.io.ObjectStreamClass.invokeReadResolve(ObjectStreamClass.java:1061)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readOrdinaryObject(ObjectInputStream.java:1762)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readObject0(ObjectInputStream.java:1329)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.defaultReadFields(ObjectInputStream.java:1947)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readSerialData(ObjectInputStream.java:1871)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readOrdinaryObject(ObjectInputStream.java:1753)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readObject0(ObjectInputStream.java:1329)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.defaultReadFields(ObjectInputStream.java:1947)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readSerialData(ObjectInputStream.java:1871)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readOrdinaryObject(ObjectInputStream.java:1753)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readObject0(ObjectInputStream.java:1329)
at java.io.ObjectInputStream.readObject(ObjectInputStream.java:351)

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: transient was defined on the wrong instance variable
